sentence: There is a shift to the cloud underway, making “cloud strategy” an important decision for companies to achieve cost optimization and increased competitiveness.
This shift is not just changing the dynamics of IT spending for customers but also leaving a powerful impact on the revenue opportunities for technology and service providers.

Here’s a peek into the alliance between Google (GOOG, GOOGL) and Cisco (CSCO) to deliver a hybrid cloud solution that helps customers maximize their investments across cloud and on-premises environments.

Cloud computing, or simply cloud, “is the delivery of on-demand computing resources—everything from applications to data centers—over the internet on a pay-for-use basis.” Cloud computing is available in multiple variations, the most popular being Software-as-a-Service (SaaS), Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) and Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS).
It can further be set up as public, private or hybrid model.

Players such as Amazon (AMZN), IBM (IBM), Google, Microsoft (MFST), Salesforce (CRM), Alibaba (BABA), Oracle (ORCL), Rackspace, and Cisco compete with one another to claim the market share, or at least maintain a stronghold on a niche segment.
The intense competition within the space isn’t without reason.

“Through 2020, an increasing percentage of annual IT spending will be directly or indirectly impacted by a cloud shift, making cloud computing one of the most disruptive forces in IT markets since the early days of the digital age,” states Gartner.
It is estimated that spending on data center systems will reach $181 billion through 2020 with IaaS constituting 39% of total spending.

The recent Q32017 report by Synergy suggests over 40% annual growth for the cloud market with Amazon Web Services (AWS) leading the market share more than its next five largest competitors combined, which include Microsoft, Google and Alibaba.

Google and Cisco are collaborating to provide a unique and open hybrid cloud offering that enables applications and services to be deployed, managed and secured across on-premises environments and Google Cloud Platform.

The deal between Cisco and Google is a breakthrough in open hybrid cloud innovation, providing development and deployment tools to organizations to increase speed and scale with enterprise-class security and support.
Google’s open source platforms—Kubernetes and Istio—lie at the heart of this architecture.
“We’re working together to deliver a consistent Kubernetes environment for both on-premises Cisco Private Cloud Infrastructure and Google’s managed Kubernetes service, Google Container Engine.
This way, you can write once, deploy anywhere and avoid cloud lock-in, with your choice of management, software, hypervisor and operating system,” wrote Google in its official blog post.
The complete solution is a healthy concoction of the individual strengths of Google and Cisco, empowering them to take on their competitors.
Google has been pushing to expand its cloud platform.
In July, it entered a partnership with Nutanix (NTNX) enterprise cloud computing, allowing customers to benefit from the blend of the Nutanix environment with Google Cloud Platform.

This was followed by Google’s tie-up with VMware (VMW) and Pivotal Software, wherein Google unveiled Pivotal Container Service (PKS)—a new product that enables enterprises and service providers to deliver production-ready Kubernetes on VMware vSphere and Google Cloud Platform.
In September, Google acquired Bitium, a provider of enterprise customers with identity and access management solutions.
The addition of Bitium to Google’s portfolio will boost cloud identity vision capabilities.
Even Cisco has been indulging in some acquisitions to strengthen its cloud capabilities.
It recently acquired BradSoft.
Bradsoft’s offerings, primarily sold to small and medium businesses, are “highly complementary” to Cisco's on-premises and enterprise-centric HCS offerings.
In August, Cisco acquired Springpath, which is expected to boost its delivery of next-generation data center innovation to its customers.
Finally, its acquisition of Observable Networks provides cloud-native network forensics security applications delivered as a service.

Earlier this year, Cisco integrated System for Microsoft Azure Stack to deliver a cloud-ready system with 40% faster infrastructure deployment and 38% reduction in ongoing management costs compared to conventional server infrastructure.
Alphabet revealed its earnings for Q32017.
While cloud business is still small in comparison to its advertising business, cloud is a key component of its future journey.
The revenue from cloud which is currently clubbed with “other revenues” for Google was up 40% year-over-year during Q3.

In the backdrop of multiple partnerships and investments into Google Cloud this year, Sundar Pichai, CEO, Google said, “That's the overall strategy and I think that's really beginning to pay off, and you will see us scale across all of these dimensions for Cloud in the year ahead.” Cisco earnings are due November 15, 2017.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
